abstract.text: Applies a Core Graphics affine transformation to an ARGB16S source image.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A pointer to a vImage buffer structure that contains the source image whose data you want to transform.
A pointer to a vImage buffer data structure. You’re responsible for filling out the
, and

fields of this structure, and for allocating a data buffer of the appropriate size. On return, the data buffer this structure points to contains the destination image data. When you no longer need the data buffer, you must deallocate the memory.
A pointer to a temporary buffer. If you pass

, the function allocates the buffer, then deallocates it before returning. Alternatively, you can allocate the buffer yourself, in which case you’re responsible for deallocating it when you no longer need it.
If you want to allocate the buffer yourself, see
for information on how to determine the minimum size that you must allocate.
The affine transformation matrix to apply to the source image.
A background color. Pass a pixel value only if you also set the
flag.
The options to use when applying the rotation.
To specify how vImage handles pixel locations beyond the edge of the source image, you must set exactly one of the following flags:
or
If you want vImage to use a higher quality, but slower resampling filter, set the
flag.
If your code implements its own tiling or its own multithreading, pass
This function ignores the
flag.
; otherwise, one of the error codes described in

Core Graphics types use float values in 32-bit and double values in 64-bit. This convenience method takes the Core Graphics affine transform type directly so that you don’t have to use a different function for 64-bit applications.
This function maps each pixel in the source image
to a new position
in the destination image, using this formula:
where
is the 3x3 affine transformation matrix.
If you want to allocate the memory for the
parameter yourself, call this function twice, as follows:
To determine the minimum size for the temporary buffer, the first time you call this function, pass the

flag. Pass the same values for all other parameters that you intend to use for the second call. The function returns the required minimum size, which should be a positive value. (A negative returned value indicates an error.) The
flag prevents the function from performing any processing other than to determine the minimum buffer size.
After you allocate enough space for a buffer of the returned size, call the function a second time, passing a valid pointer in the
parameter. This time, don’t pass the
flag.

abstract.text: Make large-scale mathematical computations and image calculations, optimized for high performance and low energy consumption.
A type for a four-channel, 16-bits-per-channel, signed pixel.
A flag that uses the background color for missing pixels.
A flag that disables vImage internal tiling routines.
A flag that extends the edges of the image infinitely.
A flag that returns the minimum temporary buffer size for the operation, given the parameters provided.
A flag that uses a higher-quality, slower resampling filter for geometry operations.
A flag that restricts the operation to red, green, and blue channels only.
The vImage function completed without error.
Applies a Core Graphics affine transformation to an ARGB16S source image.
Applies a Core Graphics affine transformation to an ARGB16U source image.
Applies a Core Graphics affine transformation to an ARGB8888 source image.
Applies a Core Graphics affine transformation to an ARGBFFFF source image.
Applies a Core Graphics affine transformation to a Planar8 source image.
Applies a Core Graphics affine transformation to a PlanarF source image.
An image buffer that stores an image’s pixel data, dimensions, and row stride.
A structure for values that represent a Core Graphics–compatible affine transformation.
A type for image errors.
A type for processing options.
Look up type aliases, data types, and constants the vImage library uses.
A pointer for accessing data of a specific type.
A raw pointer for accessing and manipulating untyped data.
A 16-bit signed integer value type.
